'''Climate-friendly gardening''' is [[gardening]] in ways which reduce emissions of [[greenhouse gases]] from [[garden]]s and encourage the absorption of [[carbon dioxide]] by [[soil]]s and [[plant]]s in order to aid the reduction of [[Climate change|global warming]].<ref name="The Climate-Friendly Gardener">{{cite web |last=Union of Concerned Scientists |title=The Climate-Friendly Gardener: A guide to combating global warming from the ground up |url=http://www.ucsusa.org/assets/documents/food_and_agriculture/climate-friendly-gardener.pdf |work=Union of Concerned Scientists |accessdate=11 March 2014}}</ref> To be a [[Sustainable living|climate-friendly]] [[gardener]] means considering both what happens in a garden and the materials brought into it and the impact they have on [[land use]] and [[climate]].<ref name="Sustainable Gardens">{{cite book |title=Sustainable Gardens |date=2009 |publisher=CSIRO |location=Collingwood, Australia |isbn=9780643094222 |first1=Rob |last1=Cross |first2=Roger |last2=Spencer}}</ref><ref name="Sustainable Gardening">{{cite book |title=Sustainable Gardening |date=2011 |publisher=The Crowood Press |location=Marlborough |isbn=9781847972323 |first=Michael |last=Lavelle}}</ref> It can also include garden features or activities in the garden that help to reduce greenhouse gas emissions elsewhere.<ref name="Science and the Garden">{{cite book |title=Science and the Garden: The scientific basis for horticultural practice |date=2008 |publisher=Blackwell Publishing |location=Chichester, Sussex, United Kingdom |isbn=9781405160636 |first1=David S. |last1=Ingram |first2=Daphne |last2=Vince-Prue |first3=Peter J. |last3=Gregory}}</ref><ref name="Ecology for Gardeners">{{cite book |title=Ecology for Gardeners |date=2004 |publisher=Timber Press |location=Portland, USA and Cambridge, UK |isbn=0881926116 |first1=Steven B. |last1=Carroll |first2=Steven B. |last2=Salt}}</ref>
[[File:Orchard garden at Hergest Croft.JPG|thumb|Orchard garden showing orchard trees, herbaceous perennials and ground-cover plants, at Hergest Croft Gardens, Herefordshire, Britain.]]
== Land use and greenhouse gases ==
Most of the excess [[greenhouse gas]]es causing [[climate change]] have come from burning [[fossil fuel]]. But a special report from the [[Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change]] (IPCC) estimated that in the last 150 years fossil fuels and [[Cement#CO2 emissions|cement production]] were responsible for only about two-thirds of climate change: the other third has been caused by human [[land use]].<ref name="Land Use, Land-Use Change and Forestry">{{cite book |title=Land Use, Land-Use Change and Forestry (Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change Special Report) |date=2000 |publisher=Cambridge University Press |location=Cambridge, UK |isbn=9780521800839 |url=http://www.ipcc.ch/ipccreports/sres/land_use/index.php?idp=0 |first1=Robert T. |last1=Watson |first2=Ian R. |last2=Noble |first3=Bert |last3=Bolin |first4=N. H. |last4=Ravindranath |first5=David J. |last5=Verardo |first6=David J. |last6=Dokken}}</ref>
The three main greenhouse gases produced by [[unsustainable]] land use are [[carbon dioxide]], [[methane]], and [[nitrous oxide]].<ref name="Science and the Garden"/><ref name="Mitigating Climate Change through Food and Land Use">{{cite book |title=Mitigating Climate Change through Food and Land Use |date=2009 |publisher=Worldwatch Institute |location=Washington, United States of America |isbn=9781878071910 |url=http://www.worldwatch.org/system/files/179%20Land%20Use.pdf |first1=Sara J. |last1=Scherr |first2=Sajal |last2=Sthapit}}</ref> [[Black carbon]] or [[soot]] can also be caused by unsustainable land use, and, although not a gas, can behave like greenhouse gases and contribute to climate change.<ref name="Ullstein editor 2011">{{cite book |editor-last=Ullstein |editor-first=Bart |title=Integrated Assessment of Black Carbon and Tropospheric Ozone: Summary for Decision-Makers |date=2011 |publisher=United Nations Environment Programme and World Meteorological Organisation |isbn=978-92-807-3142-2}}</ref><ref name="Bond 2013">{{cite journal |last1=Bond |first1=T. C. |first2=S. J. |last2=Doherty |first3=D. W. |last3=Fahey |first4=P. M. |last4=Forster |first5=T. |last5=Berntsen |first6=B. J. |last6=DeAngelo |first7=M. G. |last7=Flanner |first8=S. |last8=Ghan |first9=B. |last9=Kärcher |first10=D. |last10=Koch |first11=S. |last11=Kinne |first12=Y. |last12=Kondo |first13=P. K. |last13=Quinn |first14=M. C. |last14=Sarofi |first15=M. G. |last15=Schultz |first16=M. |last16=Schulz |first17=C. |last17=Venkataraman |first18=H. |last18=Zhang |first19=S. |last19=Zhang |first20=N. |last20=Bellouin |first21=S. K. |last21=Guttikunda |first22=P. K. |last22=Hopke |first23=M. Z. |last23=Jacobson |first24=J. W. |last24=Kaiser |first25=Z. |last25=Klimont |first26=U. |last26=Lohmann |first27=J. P. |last27=Schwarz |first28=D. |last28=Shindell |first29=T. |last29=Storelvmo |first30=S. G. |last30=Warren |first31=C. S. |last31=Zender |title=Bounding the role of black carbon in the climate system: A scientific assessment |journal=Journal of Geophysical Research: Atmospheres |date=2013 |doi=10.1002/jgrd.50171 |volume=118 |pages=5380–5552}}</ref>
=== Carbon dioxide ===
[[Carbon dioxide]], {{CO2}}, is a natural part of the [[carbon cycle]], but human [[land use]]s often add more, especially from [[habitat destruction]] and the [[Tillage|cultivation]] of [[soil]]. When [[woodland]]s, [[wetland]]s, and other natural [[habitat]]s are turned into [[pasture]], [[Arable land|arable fields]], buildings and roads, the [[Soil carbon|carbon held in the soil]] and vegetation becomes extra carbon dioxide and [[methane]] to trap more heat in the [[Atmosphere of Earth|atmosphere]].<ref name="Land Use, Land-Use Change and Forestry">{{cite book |title=Land Use, Land-Use Change and Forestry (Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change Special Report) |date=2000 |publisher=Cambridge University Press |location=Cambridge, UK |isbn=9780521800839 |url=http://www.ipcc.ch/ipccreports/sres/land_use/index.php?idp=0 |first1=Robert T. |last1=Watson |first2=Ian R. |last2=Noble |first3=Bert |last3=Bolin |first4=N. H. |last4=Ravindranath |first5=David J. |last5=Verardo |first6=David J. |last6=Dokken}}</ref>
[[Gardener]]s may cause extra carbon dioxide to be added to the atmosphere in several ways:
* Using [[peat]] or [[potting compost]] containing peat;<ref name="The Climate-Friendly Gardener"/><ref name="Science and the Garden"/><ref>{{cite book |last=Royal Horticultural Society |title=Peat and the Gardener: Conservation and Environment Guidelines |date=2009 |publisher=Royal Horticultural Society, Wisley, United Kingdom}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last=Knight |first=Alan |title=Towards Sustainable Growing Media: Chairman's Report and Roadmap |date=2013 |publisher=Department for the Environment, Food and Rural Affairs (Defra), London |url=https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/221019/pb13867-towards-sustainable-growing-media.pdf}}</ref><ref name="How to Create an Eco Garden">{{cite book |last=Walker |first=John |title=How to Create an Eco Garden: The Practical Guide to Greener, Planet-Friendly Gardening |date=2011 |publisher=Aquamarine |location=Wigston, Leicester |isbn=978-1903141892}}</ref> * Buying [[garden furniture]] or other [[wood]]en products made from woodland which has been destroyed rather than taken as a [[Renewable resource|renewable crop]] from [[Sustainable land management|sustainably managed]] woodland;<ref name="Sustainable Gardens"/> * Digging soil and leaving it bare so that the carbon in soil organic matter is [[Oxidation|oxidised]];<ref name="The Climate-Friendly Gardener"/><ref name="Science and the Garden"/> * Using [[power tool]]s which burn [[fossil fuel]] or [[electricity]] generated by burning fossil fuel;<ref name="The Climate-Friendly Gardener"/><ref name="Science and the Garden"/><ref name="How to Create an Eco Garden"/><ref name="Ecological Gardening">{{cite book |last=Cunningham |first=Sally |title=Ecological Gardening |date=2009 |publisher=The Crowood Press |location=Marlborough |isbn=978 1 84797 125 8}}</ref> * Using [[patio heater]]s; * Heating [[greenhouse]]s by burning fossil fuel or electricity generated by burning fossil fuel;<ref name="Science and the Garden"/> * Burning [[Pruning|garden pruning]]s and [[weed]]s on a [[bonfire]]; * Buying [[tools]], [[pesticide]]s, [[Fertilizer|synthetic nitrogen fertilizers]] (over 2 kilograms of carbon dioxide equivalent is produced in the manufacture of each kilogram of ammonium nitrate<ref>{{cite book |first1=Sam |last1=Wood |first2=Annette |last2=Cowie |title=A Review of Greenhouse Gas Emission Factors for Fertiliser Production |date=2004 |publisher=IEA Bioenergy}}</ref>), and other materials which have been manufactured using fossil fuel;<ref name="The Climate-Friendly Gardener"/><ref name="Sustainable Gardens"/><ref name="Science and the Garden"/><ref name="How to Create an Eco Garden"/><ref name="Julian Allwood and Jonathan Cullen 'Sustainable Materials - with both eyes open'">{{cite book |title=Sustainable Materials - with both eyes open |date=2011 |publisher=UIT |location=Cambridge |isbn=9781906860059 |url=http://www.withbotheyesopen.com/ |first1=Julian |last1=Allwood |first2=Jonathan |last2=Cullen}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last=Hammond |first=G. P. |first2=C. I. |last2=Jones |title=Embodied energy and carbon in construction materials |journal=Proceedings of the Institution of Civil Engineers - Energy |date=2008 |volume=161 |issue=2 |pages=87–98 |doi=10.1680/ener.2008.161.2.87}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last=Institute of Civil Engineers |title=Embodied Energy and Carbon |url=http://www.ice.org.uk/topics/energy/Briefing-Sheets/Embodied-Energy-and-Carbon |accessdate=11 March 2014}}</ref> * Heating and treating [[swimming pool]]s by burning fossil fuel or electricity generated by burning fossil fuel;<ref name="Sustainable Gardens"/> * [[Irrigation|Watering]] their gardens with [[tapwater]], which has been treated and pumped by burning fossil fuel, with a greenhouse gas impact of about 1 kg CO<sub>2</sub>e/m<sup>3</sup> water.<ref name="Sustainable Gardens"/><ref name="Science and the Garden"/><ref name="How to Create an Eco Garden"/><ref name="Livesley 2010 273–293">{{cite journal |last=Livesley |first=S. |first2=B. |last2=Dougherty |first3=A. |last3=Smith |first4=D. |last4=Navaud |first5=L. |last5=Wylie |first6=S. |last6=Arndt |title=Soil-atmosphere exchange of carbon dioxide, methane and nitrous oxide in urban garden systems: impact of irrigation, fertilizer and mulch |journal=Urban Ecosystems |date=2010 |volume=13 |pages=273–293 |doi=10.1007/s11252-009-0119-6}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title=Quantifying the energy and carbon effects of water saving full technical report |date=2009 |publisher=Environment Agency and Energy Saving Trust |url=http://www.energysavingtrust.org.uk/Publications2/Housing-professionals/Heating-systems/Quantifying-the-energy-and-carbon-effects-of-water-saving-full-technical-report |first1=Alan |last1=Clarke |first2=Nick |last2=Grant |first3=Judith |last3=Thornton}}</ref>
Gardeners will also be responsible for extra carbon dioxide when they buy garden products which have been transported by vehicles powered by fossil fuel.<ref name="Sustainable Gardens"/>
=== Methane === [[Methane]], CH<sub>4</sub>, is a natural part of the [[carbon cycle]], but human [[land use]]s often add more, especially from [[:wikt:anaerobic|anaerobic]] [[soil]], artificial [[wetland]]s such as [[Rice#Environmental impacts|rice fields]], and from the [[Digestion|guts]] of [[livestock|farm animals]], especially [[ruminant]]s such as [[cattle]] and [[sheep]].<ref name="Dave Reay 2010">{{cite book |title=Methane and Climate Change |date=2010 |publisher=Earthscan |location=London |isbn=978-1844078233 |first1=Dave |last1=Reay |first2=Pete |last2=Smith |first3=Andre |last3=van Amstel}}</ref>
[[Gardener]]s may cause extra methane to be added to the atmosphere in several ways:
* [[Soil compaction|Compacting]] soil so that it becomes anaerobic, for example by treading on soil when it is wet; * Allowing [[compost]] heaps to become compacted and anaerobic;<ref name="Science and the Garden"/><ref>{{cite book|author1=Harriet Kopinska |author2=Jane Griffiths |author3=Heather Jackson |author4=Pauline Pears |title=The Garden Organic Book of Compost|date=2011|publisher=New Holland|location=London|isbn=9781847734372}}</ref> * Creating homemade liquid feed by putting the leaves of plants such as [[Comfrey#Fertilizer uses|comfrey under water]], with the unintended consequence that the plants may release methane as they [[Decomposition|decay]]; * Killing pernicious [[weed]]s by covering them with water, with the unintended consequence that the plants may release methane as they decay; * Allowing [[pond]]s to become anaerobic, for example by adding unsuitable [[fish]] species which stir up sediment that then blocks light from and kills [[Water aeration#Natural aeration|submerged oxygenating plants]].<ref name="Creating a Garden Pond for Wildlife">{{cite book |title=Creating a Garden Pond for Wildlife |date=2011 |publisher=Freshwater Habitats Trust |location=Oxford |isbn=978-0-9537971-2-7 |author=Pond Conservation}}</ref>
=== Nitrous oxide ===
[[Nitrous oxide]], N<sub>2</sub>O, is a natural part of the [[nitrogen cycle]], but human [[land use]]s often add more.<ref>{{cite book |last=Smith (editor) |first=Keith |title=Nitrous Oxide and Climate Change |date=2010 |publisher=Earthscan |location=London |isbn=978-1844077571}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title=The nitrogen cycle and its influence on the European greenhouse gas balance |date=2011 |publisher=Centre for Ecology and Hydrology |isbn=978-1-906698-21-8 |first1=Mark |last1=Sutton |first2=Stefan |last2=Reis}}</ref>
Gardeners may cause extra nitrous oxide to be added to the atmosphere by:
* Using synthetic nitrogen [[fertilizer]], for example "weed and feed" on [[lawn]]s, especially if it is applied when plants are not actively growing, the soil is compacted, or when other factors are limiting so that the plants cannot make use of the nitrogen;<ref name="Livesley 2010 273–293"/><ref name="Farming Futures Fact Sheet 20">{{cite web |last=Farming Futures |title=Climate change: be part of the solution Focus on: soil management (Fact Sheet 20) |url=http://www.farmingfutures.org.uk/sites/default/files/casestudy/pdf/FF_FS20_REV_Nov09%20%28final%29.pdf |accessdate=6 July 2014}}</ref><ref name="Farming Futures Fact Sheet 21">{{cite web |last=Farming Futures |title=Climate change: be part of the solution Focus on: nutrient management (Fact Sheet 21) |url=http://www.farmingfutures.org.uk/sites/default/files/casestudy/pdf/FF_FS21_REVOCT09WEB.pdf |accessdate=6 July 2014}}</ref> * Compacting the soil (for example by working in the garden when the soil is wet) which will increase the conversion of [[Nitrate#Uses|nitrates]] to nitrous oxide by soil bacteria;<ref name="Farming Futures Fact Sheet 20"/> * Burning garden waste on [[bonfire]]s.
=== Black carbon ===
Black carbon is not a gas, but it acts like a greenhouse gas because it can be [[Suspension (chemistry)|suspended]] in the atmosphere and absorb [[Thermal energy|heat]].<ref name="Ullstein editor 2011"/><ref name="Bond 2013"/>
Gardeners may cause extra black carbon to be added to the atmosphere by burning garden [[pruning]]s and [[weed]]s on bonfires, especially if the waste is wet and becomes black carbon in the form of soot.<ref name="Ecology for Gardeners"/> Gardeners will also be responsible for extra black carbon produced when they buy garden products which have been transported by vehicles powered by [[fossil fuel]] especially the [[Diesel exhaust|diesel]] used in most lorries.
== Gardening to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and absorb carbon dioxide ==
There are many ways in which climate-friendly gardeners may reduce their contribution to climate change and help their gardens absorb [[carbon dioxide]] from the atmosphere.<ref name="The Climate-Friendly Gardener"/><ref name="Sustainable Gardens"/><ref name="Science and the Garden"/><ref name="How to Create an Eco Garden"/><ref name="Farming Futures Fact Sheet 20"/><ref>{{cite book |title=Gardening in the Global Greenhouse: The impacts of climate change on gardens in the UK |date=2002 |publisher=UK Climate Impacts Programme |location=Oxford |citeseerx = 10.1.1.131.6205 |first1=Richard |last1=Bisgrove |first2=Paul |last2=Hadley}}</ref>
Climate-friendly gardeners can find good ideas in many other [[Sustainability|sustainable]] approaches: * [[Agroforestry]]; * [[Forest gardening]]; * [[Orchard]]s; * [[Organic gardening]]; * [[Permaculture]]; * [[Rain garden]]; * [[Vegan organic gardening]]; * [[Water-wise gardening]]; * [[Wildlife garden]].
== Protecting and enhancing carbon stores ==
=== Protecting carbon stores in land beyond gardens === [[File:Woodland and wetland in the New Forest.JPG|thumb|Woodland and wetland in the New Forest, Hampshire]] [[File:Woodland and trees in Herefordshire landscape.JPG|thumb|Woodland and trees in Herefordshire]] [[File:Waterbutt in kitchen garden at Charles Darwin's home, Down House, Kent.JPG|thumb|Kitchen garden at Charles Darwin's home, Down House, Kent, showing greenhouse, waterbutt, box hedging and vegetable beds.]] [[File:Alliums in dry garden at Cambridge Botanic Garden.JPG|thumb|Alliums, lavender, box and other water-thrifty plants in the dry garden at Cambridge Botanic Garden]]
Climate-friendly gardening includes actions which protect [[Carbon cycle#Main components|carbon stores]] beyond gardens. The biggest carbon stores in land are in soil; the two habitat types with the biggest carbon stores per hectare are [[Woodland|woods]] and [[wetland]]s; and woods absorb more carbon dioxide per hectare per year than most other habitats. Climate-friendly gardeners therefore aim to ensure that nothing they do will harm these habitats.
According to Morison and Morecroft (eds.)'s ''Plant Growth and Climate Change'',<ref name="Plant Growth and Climate Change">{{cite book |title=Plant Growth and Climate Change |date=2006 |publisher=Blackwell Publishing |location=Oxford |isbn=978-14051-3192-6 |first1=James I. L. |last1=Morison |first2=Michael D. |last2=Morecroft}}</ref> the [[net primary productivity]] (the net amount of carbon absorbed each year) of various habitats <!--not encyclopedic: (they don't give a figure for wetlands)--> is:
* [[Tropical forest]]s: 12.5 tonnes of carbon per hectare per year; * [[Temperate forest]]s: 7.7 tonnes of carbon per hectare per year; * [[Grassland|Temperate grassland]]s: 3.7 tonnes of carbon per hectare per year; * [[Cropland]]s: 3.1 tonnes of carbon per hectare per year.
The [[Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change]]'s Special Report ''[[Land use, land-use change, and forestry]]'' <ref name="Land Use, Land-Use Change and Forestry"/> lists the carbon contained in different global habitats as:
* Wetlands: 643 tonnes carbon per hectare in soil + 43 tonnes carbon per hectare in vegetation = total 686 tonnes carbon per hectare; * Tropical forests: 123 tonnes carbon per hectare in soil + 120 tonnes carbon per hectare in vegetation = total 243 tonnes carbon per hectare; * Temperate forests: 96 tonnes carbon per hectare in soil + 57 tonnes carbon per hectare in vegetation = total 153 tonnes carbon per hectare; * Temperate grasslands: 164 tonnes carbon per hectare in soil + 7 tonnes carbon per hectare in vegetation = total 171 tonnes carbon per hectare; * Croplands: 80 tonnes carbon per hectare in soil + 2 tonnes carbon per hectare in vegetation = total 82 tonnes carbon per hectare.
The figures quoted above are global averages. More recent research in 2009 has found that the habitat with the world's highest known total carbon density - 1,867 tonnes of carbon per hectare - is temperate moist forest of [[Eucalyptus regnans]] in the Central Highlands of south-east [[Australia]]; and, in general, that temperate forests contain more carbon than either [[boreal forest]]s or tropical forests.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Keith |first1=Heather |first2=Brendan G. |last2=Mackey |first3=David B. |last3=Lindenmaye |title=Re-evaluation of forest biomass carbon stocks and lessons from the world's most carbon-dense forests |journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America |date=2009 |volume=106 |issue=28|doi= 10.1073/pnas.0901970106 |pages=11635–11640 |pmid=19553199 |pmc=2701447}}</ref>
===Carbon stores in Britain=== According to Milne and Brown's 1997 paper "Carbon in the vegetation and soils of Great Britain",<ref name="Carbon in the vegetation and soils of Great Britain">{{cite journal |last1=Milne |first1=R. |first2=T. A. |last2=Brown |title=Carbon in the vegetation and soils of Great Britain |journal=Journal of Environmental Management |date=1997 |volume=49 |pages=413–433 |doi=10.1006/jema.1995.0118}}</ref> [[Great Britain|Britain]]'s [[vegetation]] and soil are estimated to contain 9952 million tonnes of carbon, of which almost all is in the soil, and most in [[Scotland|Scottish]] [[bog|peatland]] soil:
* Soils in Scotland: 6948 million tonnes carbon; * Soils in [[England]] and [[Wales]]: 2890 million tonnes carbon; * Vegetation in British [[woodland|woods]] and [[plantation]]s (which cover only 11% of Britain's land area): 91 million tonnes carbon; * Other vegetation: 23 million tonnes carbon.
A 2005 report<ref>{{cite book |title=Climate Change and British Woodland |date=2005 |publisher=Forestry Commission |location=Edinburgh |isbn=0-85538-658-4 |first1=Mark |last1=Broadmeadow |first2=Duncan |last2=Ray |url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/pdf/fcin069.pdf/$FILE/fcin069.pdf}}</ref> suggested that British woodland soil may contain as much as 250 tonnes of carbon per hectare.
Many studies of [[soil carbon]] only study the carbon in the top 30 centimetres, but soil is often much deeper than that, especially below woodland. One 2009 study of the [[United Kingdom]]'s [[Carbon cycle#Main components|carbon stores]] by Keith Dyson and others gives figures for soil carbon down to 100 cm below the [[habitat]]s, including "Forestland", "Cropland" and "Grassland", covered by the [[Kyoto Protocol]] reporting requirements.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Dyson |first1=Keith |first2=A. M. |last2=Thomson |first3=D. C. |last3=Mobbs |first4=R. |last4=Milne |first5=U. |last5=Skiba |first6=A. |last6=Clark |first7=P. E. |last7=Levy |first8=S. K. |last8=Jones |first9=M. F. |last9=Billett |first10=K. J. |last10=Dinsmore |first11=M. |last11=van Oijen |first12=N. |last12=Ostle |first13=B. |last13=Foeried |first14=P. |last14=Smith |first15=R. W. |last15=Matthews |first16=E. |last16=Mackie |first17=P. |last17=Bellamy |first18=M. |last18=Rivas-Casado |first19=C. |last19=Jordan |first20=A. |last20=Higgins |first21=R. W. |last21=Tomlinson |first22=J. |last22=Grace |first23=P. |last23=Parrish |first24=M. |last24=Williams |first25=R. |last25=Clement |first26=J.|last26=Moncrieff |first27=A. |last27=Manning |title=Inventory and projections of UK emissions by sources and removals by sinks due to land use, land-use change and forestry Annual Report |publisher=Department for the Environment, Food and Rural Affairs Climate, Energy and Ozone, Science and Analysis Division |location=London |date=July 2009|url=http://ecosystemghg.ceh.ac.uk/docs/2009/Defra_Report_2009.pdf}}</ref>
* Forestland soils: average figures in tonnes carbon per hectare are 160 (England), 428 (Scotland), 203 (Wales), and 366 ([[Northern Ireland]]). * Grassland soils: average figures in tonnes carbon per hectare are 148 (England), 386 (Scotland), 171 (Wales), and 304 (Northern Ireland). * Cropland soils: average figures in tonnes carbon per hectare are 110 (England), 159 (Scotland), 108 (Wales), and 222 (Northern Ireland).
===Protecting carbon stores in wetland=== [[File:Paving - wood chip with birch logs as edging at Wisley.JPG|thumb|Permeable paving of wood chip with birch-log edging at the Royal Horticultural Society garden at Wisley]] [[File:Symphytum grandiflorum, creeping comfrey, with Cotinus coggygria.JPG|thumb|A ground-cover and rain-garden plant - Symphytum grandiflorum, creeping comfrey (with Cotinus coggygria)]] Climate-friendly gardeners choose [[peat]]-free [[Potting compost|compost]]s<ref name="The Climate-Friendly Gardener"/><ref name="Science and the Garden"/><ref name="How to Create an Eco Garden"/> because some of the planet's biggest [[Carbon cycle#Main components|carbon stores]] are in [[soil]], and especially in the [[Bog|peatland]] soil of [[wetland]]s.
The [[Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change]]'s Special Report ''Land Use, Land-Use Change and Forestry'' gives a figure of 2011 gigatonnes of carbon for global carbon stocks in the top 1 metre of soils, much more than the carbon stores in the vegetation or the atmosphere.<ref name="Land Use, Land-Use Change and Forestry"/>
Climate-friendly gardeners also avoid using [[tapwater]] not only because of the [[greenhouse gas]]es emitted when fossil fuels are burnt to treat and pump water,<ref name="The Climate-Friendly Gardener"/> but because if water is taken from wetlands then carbon stores are more likely to be oxidised to [[carbon dioxide]].<ref name="Land Use, Land-Use Change and Forestry"/>
A climate-friendly garden therefore does not contain large [[Irrigation|irrigated]] [[lawn]]s, but instead includes [[water-butt]]s to collect [[rain]]water; water-thrifty plants which survive on rainwater and do not need watering after they are established; [[tree]]s, [[shrub]]s and [[hedge]]s to [[Windbreak|shelter]] gardens from the drying effects of [[Sunlight|sun]] and [[wind]]; and [[groundcover]] plants and [[Mulch#Organic mulches|organic mulch]] to protect the soil and keep it moist.<ref name="Sustainable Gardens"/><ref name="Science and the Garden"/><ref name="Ecology for Gardeners"/><sup>p. 242</sup><ref name="How to Create an Eco Garden"/><sup>p. 80–82</sup><ref name="Gardening Without Water">{{cite book |title=Gardening Without Water: Creating beautiful gardens using only rainwater |date=1999 |publisher=Search Press |location=Tunbridge Wells |isbn=0855328851 |first=Charlotte |last=Green}}</ref>
Climate-friendly gardeners will ensure that any paved surfaces in their gardens (which are kept to a minimum to increase carbon stores) are [[Permeable paving|permeable]],<ref name="How to Create an Eco Garden"/> and may also make [[rain garden]]s, sunken areas into which rainwater from buildings and paving is directed, so that the rain can then be fed back into [[groundwater]] rather than going into [[storm drain]]s. The plants in rain gardens must be able to grow in both dry and wet soils.<ref name="Sustainable Gardens"/><ref>{{cite book |title=Rain Gardens: Managing Water Sustainably in the Garden and Designed Landscape |date=2007 |publisher=Timber Press |location=Portland, Oregon, USA |isbn=978-0881928266 |first1=Nigel |last1=Dunnett |first2=Andy |last2=Clayden}}</ref>
===Protecting carbon stores in woodland=== Wetlands may store the most carbon in their soils, but woods store more carbon in their living [[biomass]] than any other type of vegetation, and their soils store the most carbon after wetlands.<ref name="Land Use, Land-Use Change and Forestry"/> Climate-friendly gardeners therefore ensure that any wooden products they buy, such as [[garden furniture]], have been made of wood from [[Sustainable forest management|sustainably managed]] woodland.
=== Protecting and increasing carbon stores in gardens === [[File:Juglans major at Cambridge Botanic Garden.jpg|thumb|Juglans elaeopyren, an American walnut, at Cambridge Botanic Garden]]
After [[Carbonate rocks|rocks containing carbonate compounds]], soil is the biggest [[Carbon cycle#Main components|store of carbon]] on land.<ref name="Land Use, Land-Use Change and Forestry"/> Carbon is found in [[soil organic matter]], including living organisms ([[Root|plant roots]], [[fungi]], [[animal]]s, [[protist]]s, [[bacteria]]), dead organisms, and [[humus]].<ref name="Science and the Garden"/> One study of the environmental benefits of gardens estimates that 86% of carbon stores in gardens is in the soil.<ref name="The domestic garden – its contribution to urban green infrastructure">{{cite journal |last1=Cameron |first1=Ross W. F. |first2=Tijana |last2=Blanuša |first3=Jane E. |last3=Taylor |first4=Andrew |last4=Salisbury |first5=Andrew J. |last5=Halstead |first6=Béatrice |last6=Henricot |first7=Ken |last7=Thompson |title=The domestic garden – its contribution to urban green infrastructure |journal=Urban Forestry & Urban Greening |date=2012 |volume=11 |issue=2 |pages=129–137 |doi=10.1016/j.ufug.2012.01.002}}</ref>
[[File:Fragaria vesca, wild strawberry.JPG|thumb|Wild strawberries in flower below a British hedge.]]
The first priorities for climate-friendly gardeners are, therefore, to: * Protect the soil's existing carbon stores; * Increase the soil's carbon stores.
To protect the soil, climate-friendly gardens: * Are based on [[plant]]s rather than buildings and paving;<ref name="Ecological Gardening"/><ref name="The domestic garden – its contribution to urban green infrastructure"/> * Have soil that is kept at a relatively stable temperature by [[Windbreak|shelter]] from trees, shrubs and/or hedges;<ref name="New Gardening">{{cite book |last=Wilson |first=Matthew |title=New Gardening: How to garden in a changing climate |date=2007 |publisher=Mitchell Beazley and the Royal Horticultural Society |location=London |isbn=9781845333058}}</ref> * Have soil that is always kept covered and therefore moist and at a relatively stable temperature by [[groundcover]] plants, fast-growing [[green manure]]s (which can be used as an [[Intercropping|intercrop]] in [[kitchen garden]]s of [[Annual plant|annual]] vegetables) and/or [[Mulch#Organic mulches|organic mulches]].<ref name="The Climate-Friendly Gardener"/><ref name="New Gardening"/><ref name="Creating a Forest Garden">{{cite book |last=Crawford |first=Martin |title=Creating a Forest Garden: Working with nature to grow edible crops |date=2010 |publisher=Green Books |location=Hartland, Devon |isbn=9781900322621}}</ref>
[[File:Soil improvement and protection - wood chip mulch at Wisley.JPG|thumb|Mulch of woodchips protecting soil at the Royal Horticultural Society garden at Wisley in Surrey.]]
Climate-friendly gardeners avoid things which may harm soil. They do not tread on the soil when it is wet, because it is then most vulnerable to compaction. They [[Tillage|dig]] as little is possible, and only when the soil is moist rather than wet, because cultivation increases the [[oxidation]] of soil organic matter and produces [[carbon dioxide]].<ref name="Sustainable Gardens"/><ref name="How to Create an Eco Garden"/><sup>p. 54–55</sup><ref name="The domestic garden – its contribution to urban green infrastructure"/><ref name="New Gardening"/><ref name="Department of the Environment, Food and Rural Affairs 2013 12">{{cite book |last=Department of the Environment, Food and Rural Affairs |title=Protecting our Water, Soil and Air: A Code of Good Agricultural Practice for farmers, growers and land managers |date=2013 |publisher=The Stationery Office |location=London |isbn=978 0 11 243284 5 |page=12}}</ref>
To increase soil carbon stores, climate-friendly gardeners ensure that their gardens create optimal conditions for vigorous healthy growth of plants, and other garden organisms above and below ground, and reduce the impact of any [[limiting factor]]s.
In general, the more [[Biomass (ecology)|biomass]] that the plants can create each year, the more carbon will be added to the soil.<ref name="How to Create an Eco Garden"/><sup>p. 54–55</sup><ref name="Creating a Forest Garden"/> However, only some biomass each year becomes long-term [[soil carbon]] or humus. In ''Soil Carbon and Organic Farming'', a 2009 report for the [[Soil Association]], Gundula Azeez discusses several [[Environmental factor|factor]]s which increase how much biomass is turned into humus. These include good [[soil structure]], [[Soil biology|soil organisms]] such as fine [[root hair]]s, [[microorganism]]s, [[mycorrhiza]]s and [[earthworm]]s which increase [[Soil#Structure|soil aggregation]], residues from plants (such as trees and shrubs) which have a high content of resistant chemicals such as [[lignin]], and plant residues with a [[carbon to nitrogen ratio]] lower than about 32:1.<ref name="Soil Carbon and Organic Farming">{{cite book |last=Azeez |first=Gundula |title=Soil Carbon and Organic Farming: A review of the evidence on the relationship between agriculture and soil carbon sequestration, and how organic farming can contribute to climate change mitigation and adaptation |date=2009 |publisher=The Soil Association |location=Bristol |url=http://www.soilassociation.org/LinkClick.aspx?fileticket=SSnOCMoqrXs%3D&tabid=387}}</ref>
[[File:Soil fertility - nitrogen fixation by root nodules on Wistaria roots, with hazelnut to show size.JPG|thumb|Nitrogen-fixing nodules on Wisteria roots (hazelnut for scale)]]
Climate-friendly gardens therefore include:
* Hedges for shelter from wind;<ref name="New Gardening"/><ref name="Creating a Forest Garden"/> * A light canopy of late-leafing [[deciduous]] trees to let in enough [[sunlight]] for growth but not so much that the garden becomes too hot and dry<ref name="Creating a Forest Garden"/> (this is one of the principles behind many [[agroforestry]] systems, such as [[Paulownia]]'s use in China partly because it is late-leafing and its [[Canopy (biology)|canopy]] is sparse so that [[crop]]s below it get shelter but also enough light<ref>{{cite book |title=Temperate Agroforestry Systems |date=1997 |publisher=CAB International |location=Wallingford, Oxfordshire |isbn=9780851991474 |author=Yungying Wu |author2=Zhaohua Zhu |pages=170–172 |editor1-first=Andrew M. |editor1-last=Gordon |editor2-first=Steven M. |editor2-last=Newman |chapter=Temperate Agroforestry in China}}</ref>); * Groundcover plants and organic mulches (such as [[woodchips]] over [[compost]] made from kitchen and garden "waste") to keep soil moist and at relatively stable temperatures;<ref name="New Gardening"/><ref name="Creating a Forest Garden"/> * [[Nitrogen fixation#Root nodule symbioses|Nitrogen-fixing plants]], because soil nitrogen may be a limiting factor (but climate-friendly gardeners avoid [[Fertilizer#Inorganic commercial fertilizer|synthetic nitrogen fertilizers]], because these may cause mycorrhizal associations to break down);<ref name="Creating a Forest Garden"/> * Many layers<ref name="Creating a Forest Garden"/> of plants, including [[Lignin|woody]] plants such as trees<ref name="How to Create an Eco Garden"/> and shrubs, other [[Perennial plant|perennials]], groundcover plants, deep-rooted plants, all chosen according to 'right plant, right place',<ref>{{cite book |last=Ferguson |first=Nicola |title=Right Plant, Right Place |date=1986 |publisher=Pan |location=London |isbn=0 330 29656 6}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last=Lancaster |first=Roy |title=Perfect Plant, Perfect Place |date=2010 |publisher=Dorling Kindersley |location=London |isbn=978-1405348133}}</ref> so that they are suited to their growing conditions and will grow well; * A wide [[biodiversity|diversity]] of [[Plant disease resistance|disease-resistant]], vigorous plants for [[Resilience (ecology)|resilience]] and to make the most of all available [[ecological niche]]s;<ref name="The domestic garden – its contribution to urban green infrastructure"/><ref name="Creating a Forest Garden"/> * Plants to [[Wildlife garden|feed and shelter]] wildlife, to increase total biomass, and to ensure [[Biological pest control|biological control]] of pests and diseases.<ref name="How to Create an Eco Garden 54-55">{{cite book|last=Walker|first=John|title=How to Create an Eco Garden: The Practical Guide to Greener, Planet-Friendly Gardening|date=2011|publisher=Anness Publishing|location=Wigston, Leicestershire|isbn=9781903141892|pages=54–55}}</ref><ref name="Ecological Gardening" /><ref name="How to Make a Wildlife Garden">{{cite book|last=Baines|first=Chris|title=How to Make a Wildlife Garden|date=2000|publisher=Frances Lincoln|location=London|isbn=9780711217119}}</ref> * Compost made from garden and kitchen "waste".<ref name="How to Create an Eco Garden"/>
Lawns, like other grasslands, can build up good levels of [[soil carbon]],<ref name="Soil Carbon and Organic Farming"/> but they will grow more vigorously and store more carbon if besides [[Lawn#Grasses|grasses]] they also contain nitrogen-fixing plants such as [[clover]],<ref name="Science and the Garden"/> and if they are cut using a [[Lawn mower#Other notable types|mulching mower]] which returns finely-chopped mowings to the lawn. More carbon, however, may be stored by other perennial plants such as trees<ref name="How to Create an Eco Garden"/> and shrubs. They also do not need to be maintained using [[power tool]]s.
Climate-friendly gardeners will also aim to increase biodiversity not only for the sake of the wildlife itself, but so that the garden ecosystem is resilient and more likely to store as much carbon as possible as long as possible. They will therefore avoid pesticides,<ref name="How to Create an Eco Garden"/> and increase the diversity of the habitats within their gardens.
== Reducing greenhouse gas emissions == Climate-friendly gardeners can directly reduce the greenhouse gas emissions from their own gardens, but can also use their gardens to indirectly reduce greenhouse gas emissions elsewhere.
=== Using gardens to reduce greenhouse gas emissions ===
Climate-friendly gardeners can use their gardens in ways which reduce [[greenhouse gas]]es elsewhere, for example by using the [[sunlight|sun]] and [[wind]] to dry [[Laundry|washing]] on [[Clothes line|washing lines]] in the garden instead of using [[electricity]] [[Electricity generation|generated]] by [[fossil fuel]] to dry washing in [[Clothes dryer|tumble dryers]].
====From farmland==== [[File:Juglans regia, walnut, with ripening nuts.JPG|thumb|Walnut, Juglans regia, with ripening walnuts]] Food is a major contributor to climate change. In the United Kingdom, according to Tara Garnett of the [http://www.fcrn.org.uk/ Food Food Climate Research Network], food contributes 19% of the country's greenhouse gas emissions.<ref name="Cooking up a Storm">{{cite book |last=Garnett |first=Tara |title=Cooking up a Storm: Food, greenhouse gas emissions and our changing climate |date=September 2008 |publisher=Food Climate Research Network, Centre for Environmental Strategy, University of Surrey |location=Guildford, Surrey |url=http://www.fcrn.org.uk/sites/default/files/CuaS_web.pdf}}</ref>
Soil is the biggest [[Carbon cycle#Main components|store of carbon]] on [[land]]. It is therefore important to protect the [[soil organic matter]] in [[Agricultural land|farmland]]. Farm animals, however, especially free-range pigs, may cause erosion, and cultivation of the soil increases the [[oxidation]] of soil organic matter into [[carbon dioxide]].<ref name="Department of the Environment, Food and Rural Affairs 2013 12"/> Other sources of greenhouse gases from farmland include: compaction caused by farm machinery or overgrazing by [[Livestock|farm animals]] can make soil [[:wikt:anaerobic|anaerobic]] and produce [[methane]]; farm animals produce methane; and [[Fertilizer#Inorganic commercial fertilizer|nitrogen fertilizer]]s can be converted to [[nitrous oxide]].
Most farmland consists of [[Arable land|fields growing annual arable crops]] which are eaten directly by people or fed to farm animals, and [[grassland]] used as [[pasture]], [[hay]] or [[silage]] to feed farm animals. Some [[Perennial crop|perennial food plants]] are also grown, such as [[fruit]]s and [[Nut (fruit)|nut]]s in [[orchard]]s, and [[watercress]] grown in water.
Although all cultivation of the soil in arable fields produces carbon dioxide, some arable crops cause more damage to soil than others. [[List of root vegetables|Root crops]] such as [[potato]]es and [[sugar-beet]], and crops which are harvested not just once a year but over a long period such as [[Leaf vegetable|green vegetables and salads]], are considered "high risk" in [[catchment-sensitive farming]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Department for the Environment, Food and Rural Affairs |title=Soil Protection Review 2010 |date=2009 |publisher=Department for the Environment, Food and Rural Affairs |location=London |pages=21–22 |url=http://adlib.everysite.co.uk/resources/000/145/513/PB13311.pdf}}</ref><ref name="Farming Futures Fact Sheet 10">{{cite web |last=Farming Futures |title=Focus on arable crops (Fact Sheet 10) |url=http://www.farmingfutures.org.uk/sites/default/files/casestudy/pdf/FF_FS_REV_FS10_Arable%20crops.pdf |accessdate=10 July 2014}}</ref>
Climate-friendly gardeners therefore grow at least some of their food,<ref name="How to Create an Eco Garden"/> and may choose [[Agriculture|food crops]] which therefore help to keep carbon in farmland [[soil]]s if they grow such high-risk crops in small [[Kitchen garden|vegetable plots]] in their gardens, where it is easier to protect the soil than in large fields under [[Commercial agriculture|commercial]] pressures. Climate-friendly gardeners may grow and eat plants such as sweet [[cicely]] which sweeten food, and so reduce the land area needed for sugar-beet.<ref name="Plants for a Future">{{cite book |last=Fern |first=Ken |title=Plants for a Future: Edible and useful plants for a healthier world |date=1997 |publisher=Permanent Publications |location=Clanfield, Hampshire |isbn=9781856230117}}</ref> They may also choose to grow [[Perennial plant|perennial]] food plants to not only reduce their indirect greenhouse gas emissions from farmland, but also to increase carbon stores in their own gardens.<ref name="Creating a Forest Garden"/><ref name="Plants for a Future"/><ref>{{cite book |last=Hart |first=Robert |title=Forest Gardening |date=1991 |publisher=Green Books |location=Hartland, Devon |isbn=1870098447}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last=Toensmeier |first=E. |title=Perennial Vegetables |date=2007 |publisher=Chelsea Green |location=Vermont, United States of America |isbn=9781931498401}}</ref>
Grassland contains more carbon per hectare than arable fields, but farm animals, especially [[ruminant]]s such as [[cattle]] or [[sheep]], produce large amounts of [[methane]], directly and from manure heaps and slurry.<ref name="Dave Reay 2010"/> Slurry and manure may also produce nitrous oxide.<ref name="Farming Futures Fact Sheet 21"/><ref name="Farming Futures Fact Sheet 4">{{cite web |last=Farming Futures |title=Climate change series: General ways to mitigate climate change (Fact Sheet 4) |url=http://www.farmingfutures.org.uk/sites/default/files/casestudy/pdf/FF_FS4_Mitigation_WEB_Oct%202008.pdf |accessdate=6 July 2014}}</ref> Gardeners who want to reduce their greenhouse gas emissions can help themselves to eat less [[meat]] and [[dairy produce]] by growing [[Nut (fruit)|nut]] trees which are a good source of [[Umami|tasty]], [[protein]]-rich [[food]], including [[walnut]]s which are an excellent source of the [[Omega-3|omega-3 fatty acid]] [[alpha-linolenic acid]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Lyle |first=Susanna |title=Ultimate Fruit & Nuts: A comprehensive guide to the cultivation, uses and health benefits of over 300 food-producing plants |date=2006 |publisher=Frances Lincoln |location=London |isbn=978-0-7112-2593-0}}</ref>
Researchers and farmers are investigating and improving ways of farming which are more sustainable, such as [[agroforestry]], [[forest farming]], [[Conservation agriculture|wildlife-friendly farming]], [[soil management]], [[catchment-sensitive farming]] (or water-friendly farming<ref>{{cite web |last1=Freshwater Habitats Trust |title=Water-Friendly Farming |url=http://www.freshwaterhabitats.org.uk/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2013/09/Water-Friendly-Farming-Introduction.pdf |website=Freshwater Habitats Trust |accessdate=9 July 2014}}</ref>). For example, the organisation [http://www.farmingfutures.org.uk Farming Futures] assists farmers in the United Kingdom to reduce their farms' greenhouse gas emissions.<ref name="Farming Futures Fact Sheet 23">{{cite web |last=Farming Futures |title=Climate change: be part of the solution Focus on energy efficiency (Fact Sheet 23) |url=http://www.farmingfutures.org.uk/sites/default/files/casestudy/pdf/FF_FS23_Energy%20efficiency.pdf |accessdate=10 July 2014}}</ref>
Farmers are aware that consumers are increasingly asking for "green credentials". Gardeners who understand climate-friendly practices can advocate their use by farmers.<ref name="The Climate-Friendly Gardener"/>
====From industry==== [[File:Elaeagnus umbellatus at the Agroforestry Research Trust forest garden.JPG|thumb|Nitrogen-fixing and edible - Elaeagnus umbellatus at the Agroforestry Research Trust forest garden in Devon]] Climate-friendly gardeners aim to reduce their consumption in general.<ref name="How to Create an Eco Garden"/> In particular, they try to avoid or reduce their consumption of tapwater because of the greenhouse gases emitted when fossil fuels are burnt to supply the energy needed to treat and pump it to them.<ref name="The Climate-Friendly Gardener"/> Instead, gardeners can garden using only rainwater.<ref name="Sustainable Gardens"/><ref name="Gardening Without Water"/>
Greenhouse gases are produced in the [[Manufacturing|manufacture]] of many materials and products used by [[gardener]]s. For example, it takes a lot of [[Energy industry|energy]] to produce [[Fertilizer#Inorganic commercial fertilizer|synthetic fertilizer]]s, especially nitrogen fertilizers. [[Ammonium nitrate]], for example, has an [[embodied energy]] of 67000 kilojoules/kilogramme,<ref name="Sustainable Gardens"/> so [[Sustainable living|climate-friendly]] gardeners will choose alternative ways of ensuring the soil in their gardens has optimal levels of nitrogen by alternative means such as [[Nitrogen fixation#Root nodule symbioses|nitrogen-fixing plants]].
Climate-friendly gardeners will also aim to follow "[[cradle-to-cradle design]]" and "[[circular economy]]" principles: when they choose to buy or make something, it should be possible to take it apart again and [[Recycling|recycle]] or [[compost]] every part, so that there is no waste, only [[Natural resource|raw materials]] to be made into something else.<ref name="Cradle to Cradle: Re-making the Way We Make Things">{{cite book |last=Braungart and McDonough |first=Michael and William |title=Cradle to Cradle: Re-making the Way We Make Things |date=2009 |publisher=Vintage, Random House |location=London |isbn=9780099535478}}</ref> This will reduce the greenhouse gases otherwise produced when [[Natural resource#Extraction|extracting]] raw materials.
====From transport==== Gardeners can reduce not only their [[food miles]] by growing some of their own food, but also their "gardening miles" by reducing the amount of plants and other materials they import, obtaining them as locally as possible and with as little packaging as possible. This might include ordering plants by [[mail order]] from a specialist nursery if the plants are sent out [[Bare root|bare-root]], reducing transport demand and the use of [[peat]]-based composts; or growing plants from [[seed]], which will also increase [[genetic diversity]] and therefore [[Resilience (ecology)|resilience]]; or growing plants [[Vegetative reproduction|vegetatively]] from [[Cutting (plant)|cutting]]s or [[Offset (botany)|offset]]s from other local gardeners; or buying reclaimed materials from salvage firms.<ref name="How to Create an Eco Garden"/>
====From houses==== [[File:Parthenocissus tricuspidata, Boston ivy, in autumn colours.JPG|thumb|Climbers as insulation - Boston ivy, Parthenocissus tricuspidata, Boston ivy, in autumn]] Climate-friendly gardeners can use their gardens in ways which reduce greenhouse gas emissions from homes by:
* Using sunlight and wind to dry washing on washing lines instead of fossil fuel-generated electricity to run [[Clothes dryer|tumble dryer]]s; * Planting [[deciduous]] [[Vine|climber]]s on houses and planting deciduous trees at suitable distances from the house to provide shade during the summer, reducing the consumption of electricity for [[HVAC#Air conditioning|air conditioning]], but also such that at cooler times of year, sunlight can reach and warm a house, reducing [[HVAC#Heating|heating]] costs and consumption;<ref name="Ecology for Gardeners"/><ref name="The domestic garden – its contribution to urban green infrastructure"/> * Planting hedges, trees, shrubs and climbers to shelter houses from wind, reducing heating costs and consumption during the winter (as long as any planting does not create a [[Wind tunnel|wind-tunnel]] effect).<ref name="Ecology for Gardeners"/><sup>p. 243</sup><ref name="The domestic garden – its contribution to urban green infrastructure"/>
Climate-friendly gardeners may also choose to reduce their own personal greenhouse gas emissions by growing and eating [[carminative]] plants such as [[fennel]] and [[garlic]] which reduce intestinal gases such as methane.<ref>{{cite book |title=The Living Gut |date=2008 |publisher=Nottingham University Press |isbn=9781904761570 |first1=W. N. |last1=Ewing |first2=Lucy |last2=Tucker}}</ref>
=== Reducing greenhouse gas emissions from gardens === [[File:Taxus baccata, yew, as internal hedge at Down House.JPG|thumb|Slow-growing yew, Taxus baccata, as hedge at Charles Darwin's home, Down House, Kent]] [[File:Trifolium pratense and Trifolium repens, red and white clover within meadow.JPG|thumb|Nitrogen-fixing red and white clover (Trifolium) as lawn plants]] [[File:Soil improvement - leaf cage, compost heap and wormery at Wisley.JPG|thumb|Leaf cage, compost heap and wormery at the Royal Horticultural Society garden at Wisley]]
There are some patent sources of greenhouse gas emissions in gardens and some more latent.
[[Power tool]]s which are powered by [[Diesel fuel|diesel]] or [[petrol]], or [[electricity]] [[Electricity generation|generated]] by burning other [[fossil fuel]]s, emit [[carbon dioxide]]. Climate-friendly gardeners may therefore choose to use [[Garden tool|hand tool]]s rather than power tools, or power tools powered by renewable electricity,<ref name="How to Create an Eco Garden"/> or [[Garden design|design their gardens]] to reduce or remove a need to use power tools. For example, they may choose dense, slow-growing species for [[hedge]]s so that the hedges only need to be cut once a year.<ref name="Ecological Gardening"/>
Lawns need[?] to be cut by lawn mowers and, in drier parts of the world, are often irrigated by tapwater. Climate-friendly gardeners will therefore do what they can to reduce this consumption by:
* Replacing part of or all lawns with other perennial planting such as trees and shrubs with less ecologically demanding maintenance requirements; * Cut some or all lawns only once or twice a year, i.e. convert them into [[meadow]]s; * Make lawn shapes simple so that they may be cut quickly; * Increase the cutting height of mower blades; * Use a mulching mower to return organic matter to the soil; * Sow [[clover]] to increase vigour (without the need for synthetic fertilisers) and resilience in dry periods; * Cut lawns with [[Lawn mower#Electricity|electric mower]]s using electricity from [[renewable energy]]; * Cut lawns with hand tools such as [[Lawn mower#By hand|push mower]]s or [[scythe]]s.<ref name="The Climate-Friendly Gardener"/><ref name="Science and the Garden"/><ref name="How to Create an Eco Garden"/><ref name="New Gardening"/>
Greenhouses can be used to grow crops which might otherwise be imported from warmer climates, but if they are heated by fossil fuel then they may cause more greenhouse gas emissions than they save. Climate-friendly gardeners will therefore use their greenhouses carefully by:
* Choosing only annual plants which will only be in the greenhouse during warmer months, or perennial plants which do not need any extra heat during winter; * Using water tanks as heat stores and compost heaps as heat sources inside greenhouses so that they stay frost-free in winter.
Climate-friendly gardeners will not put woody prunings on bonfires, which will emit carbon dioxide and black carbon,<ref name="Ecology for Gardeners"/> but instead burn them indoors in a [[wood-burning stove]] and therefore cut emissions from fossil fuel, or cut them up to use as [[mulch]] and increase soil carbon stores,<ref name="How to Create an Eco Garden"/> or add the smaller prunings to compost heaps to keep them [[Aeration|aerated]], reducing [[methane emissions]].<ref>{{cite book|author1=Harriet Kopinska |author2=Jane Griffiths |author3=Heather Jackson |author4=Pauline Pears |title=The Garden Organic Book of Compost|date=2011|publisher=New Holland|location=London|isbn=9781847734372}}</ref> To reduce the risk of fire, they will also choose fire-resistant plants from habitats which are not prone to [[wildfire]]s and which do not catch fire easily, rather than fire-adapted [[Wildfire#Plant adaptation|plants from fire-prone habitats]] which are flammable and adapted to encourage fires and then gain a competitive advantage over less resistant species.
Climate-friendly gardeners may use deep-rooted plants such as [[comfrey]] to bring nutrients closer to the surface topsoil, but will do so without making the leaves into a liquid feed, because the rotting leaves in the [[Hypoxia (environmental)#Aquatic hypoxia|anaerobic]] conditions under water may emit methane.
[[Fertilizer#Inorganic commercial fertilizer|Nitrogen fertilizer]]s may be [[Nitrous oxide#Soil|oxidised]] to [[nitrous oxide]],<ref name="How to Create an Eco Garden"/> especially if fertilizer is applied in excess, or when plants are not actively growing. Climate-friendly gardeners may choose instead to use [[Nitrogen fixation#Root nodule symbioses|nitrogen-fixing]] plants which will add nitrogen to the soil without increasing nitrous oxide emissions.

The '''Clock Constraint Specification Language''' or '''CCSL''', is a software language for modeling relations among so-called clocks. It is part of the time model defined in the UML Profile for [[Modeling and Analysis of Real Time and Embedded systems|MARTE]].<ref>http://www.omgmarte.org/</ref>
CCSL provides a concrete syntax to handle [[logical clock]]s. The term '''logical clock''' refers to [[Leslie Lamport]]'s logical clocks and its usage in CCSL is directly inspired from [[Synchronous programming language]]s (like [[Esterel]] or Signal).
A [[solver]] of CCSL constraints is implemented in the TimeSquare tool.<ref>http://timesquare.inria.fr/</ref>

In [[particle physics]], '''composite Higgs models''' (CHM) are speculative extensions of the [[Standard Model]] (SM) where the [[Higgs boson]] is a [[bound state]] of new strong interactions. These scenarios are the leading alternative to [[supersymmetric]] models for physics beyond the SM presently tested at the [[Large Hadron Collider]] (LHC) in Geneva.
According to CHM the recently discovered [[Higgs boson]] is not an [[elementary particle]] (or point-like) but has finite size, typically around 10<sup>−18</sup> meters. This dimension is related to the [[electroweak scale|Fermi scale]] (100 GeV) that determines the strength of the [[weak interactions]] such as in [[β-decay]]. Microscopically the composite Higgs will be made of smaller constituents in the same way as nuclei are made [[protons]] and [[neutrons]].
The main prediction of CHM are new particles with mass around a [[TeV]] that are [[excited state|excitations]] of the composite Higgs. This is analogous to the resonances in [[nuclear physics]]. The new particles could be produced and detected in collider experiments if the energy of the collision exceeds their mass and/or could produce deviations from the SM predictions in "low energy observables" — results of experiments at lower energies. Within the most compelling scenarios each Standard Model particle has a partner with equal quantum numbers but heavier mass. For example, the [[photon]], [[W and Z bosons]] have heavy replicas with mass determined by the compositeness scale, expected around 1 TeV.
CHM are motivated by the so-called naturalness or [[hierarchy problem]] of the SM,<ref>G. F. Giudice, ''Naturalness after LHC8'', PoS EPS HEP2013, 163 (2013) https://arxiv.org/pdf/1307.7879.pdf.</ref> the difficulty to explain the different energy scales that appear in the fundamental interactions of particle physics, in particular, the large difference between the mass of the Higgs boson and the [[Planck scale]]. CHM can solve the naturalness problem because the Higgs boson is not an elementary particle so that a new energy scale exists that can be explained dynamically similarly to the mass of the proton. Naturalness requires that new particles exist with mass around a TeV and these could be discovered at LHC or future experiments. As of 2018, no direct or indirect signs that the Higgs or other SM particles are composite has been detected.
== History == CHM were introduced in the early '80s as an extension of [[Technicolor (physics)|technicolor]] theories to allow for the presence of a physical Higgs boson. At the time this was not required by the data but recent discoveries have shown the necessity of a physical Higgs doublet to break the [[electroweak interaction|electro-weak symmetry]]. This differs from ordinary technicolor theories where strong dynamics directly breaks the electro-weak symmetry without the need of a physical Higgs boson. The first CHM proposed by Georgi and Kaplan were based on known [[gauge theory]] dynamics<ref>M. J. Dugan, H. Georgi and D. B.Kaplan, ''Anatomy of a Composite Higgs Model'', Nucl. Phys. B254, 299 (1985).</ref> that produces the Higgs doublet as a [[Goldstone boson]]. These models are very constrained and it is difficult to include [[fermion]] masses. The subject remained dormant for several years until it was realized that this type of models naturally arise in 5 dimensional theories known as [[Randall–Sundrum]] scenarios. Within these constructions enough freedom exists to build realistic models at the price of abandoning a full microscopic description. It was soon understood that these scenarios can also be realized in hypothetical strongly coupled [[conformal field theory|conformal field theories]] (CFT) also providing a dynamical explanation for the generation of hierarchies. The connection between Randall-Sundrum models and CFTs is rooted in the [[AdS-CFT|AdS-CFT correspondence]]. This spurred a great deal of activity in the field. At first the Higgs was a generic scalar bound state. In the highly influential work<ref>K. Agashe, R. Contino and A. Pomarol, ''The Minimal composite Higgs model'', Nucl. Phys. B719, 165 (2005) https://arxiv.org/pdf/hep-ph/0412089.pdf.</ref> the Higgs as a Goldstone boson was realized in Randall-Sundrum models and in CFTs. Detailed phenomenological studies showed that within this framework agreement with experimental data can be obtained with a mild [[fine-tuning|tuning]] of parameters.
== Models == CHM can be characterized by the mass (M) of the lightest new particles and their coupling (g). The latter is expected to be larger than the SM couplings for consistency. Various realizations of CHM exist that differ for the mechanism that generates the Higgs doublet. Broadly they can be divided in two categories: # Higgs is a generic bound state of strong dynamics. # Higgs is a Goldstone boson of spontaneous symmetry breaking<ref>R. Contino, ''The Higgs as a Composite Nambu-Goldstone Boson'', https://arxiv.org/pdf/1005.4269.pdf.</ref><ref>M. Redi, https://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&pid=sites&srcid=ZGVmYXVsdGRvbWFpbnxyZWRpNzZ8Z3g6YjZlZDk5NDU4NTBjMmU5</ref> In both cases the electro-weak symmetry is broken by the [[Bose-Einstein condensate|condensation]] of a Higgs scalar doublet. In the first type of scenario there is no a priori reason why the Higgs boson is lighter than the other composite states and moreover larger deviations from the SM are expected.
=== Higgs as Goldstone boson === In this scenario the existence of the Higgs boson follows from the symmetries of the theory. This allows to explain why this particle is lighter than the rest of the composite particles whose mass is expected from direct and indirect tests to be around a TeV or higher. It is assumed that the composite sector has a global symmetry G [[spontaneous symmetry breaking|spontaneously broken]] to a subgroup H where G and H are compact [[Lie groups]]. Contrary to [[technicolor]] models the unbroken symmetry must contain the SM electro-weak group SU(2)xU(1). According to [[Goldstone's theorem]] the spontaneous breaking of a global symmetry produces massless scalar particles known as [[Goldstone bosons]]. By appropriately choosing the [[global symmetry|global symmetries]] it is possible to have Goldstone bosons that correspond to the Higgs doublet in the SM. This can be done in a variety of ways<ref>J. Mrazek, A. Pomarol, R. Rattazzi, M. Redi, J. Serra and A. Wulzer, ''The Other Natural Two Higgs Doublet Model'', Nucl. Phys. B853, 1 (2011) https://arxiv.org/pdf/1105.5403.pdf.</ref> and is completely determined by the symmetries. In particular [[group theory]] determines the [[quantum numbers]] of the Goldstone bosons. From the decomposition of the adjoint representation one finds, :<math>\rm{Adj}[G]={\rm Adj}[H]+{\rm R}[\Pi]</math> where R[Π] is the representation of the Goldstone bosons under H. The phenomenological request that a Higgs doublet exists selects the possible symmetries. Typical example is the pattern :<math>\frac {SO(5)}{SU(2)_L\times SU(2)_R}\rightarrow GB=(2,2)</math> that contains a single Higgs doublet as a Goldstone boson.
The physics of the Higgs as a Goldstone boson is strongly constrained by the symmetries and determined by the symmetry breaking scale f that controls their interactions. An approximate relation exists between mass and coupling of the composite states, <math>M=g f</math> In CHM one finds that deviations from the SM are proportional to, :<math>\xi=\frac {v^2}{f^2}</math> where v=246 GeV is the [[electro-weak]] vacuum expectation value. By construction these models approximate the SM to arbitrary precision if ξ is sufficiently small. For example, for the model above with SO(5) global symmetry the coupling of the Higgs to W and Z bosons is modified as, :<math>\frac{h_{VV}}{h_{VV}^{SM}}\approx 1-\frac {\xi} 2 </math> Phenomenological studies suggest f > 1 TeV and thus at least a factor of a few larger than v. However the tuning of parameters required to achieve v < f is inversely proportional to ξ so that viable scenarios require some degree of tuning.
Goldstone bosons generated from the spontaneous breaking of an exact global symmetry are ''exactly'' massless. Therefore if the Higgs boson is a Goldstone boson the global symmetry cannot be exact. In CHM the Higgs potential is generated by effects that explicitly break the global symmetry G. Minimally these are the SM Yukawa and gauge couplings that cannot respect the global symmetry but other effects can also exist. The [[top quark|top]] coupling is expected to give a dominant contribution to the Higgs potential as this is the largest coupling in the SM. In the simplest models one finds a correlation between the Higgs mass and the mass M of the top partners,<ref>M. Redi and A. Tesi, ''Implications of a Light Higgs in Composite Models'', JHEP 1210, 166 (2012) https://arxiv.org/pdf/1205.0232.pdf.</ref> :<math>m_h^2\sim \frac {3}{2\pi^2} \frac {M^2}{f^2} v^2</math> In models with f~TeV as suggested by naturalness this indicates fermionic resonances with mass around 1 TeV. Spin-1 resonances are expected to be somewhat heavier. This is within the reach of future collider experiments.
=== Partial compositeness === One of the key ingredients of modern realizations of CHM is the hypothesis of partial compositeness originally proposed by D. B. Kaplan.<ref>D. B. Kaplan, ''Flavor at SSC energies: A New mechanism for dynamically generated fermion masses'', Nucl. Phys. B 365, 259 (1991).</ref> This hypothesis is automatically realized in Randall-Sundrum scenarios. Every SM particle has a heavy partner that can mix with it. In practice the SM particles are linear combinations of elementary and composite states: :<math>|SM\rangle=\cos{\alpha} |El>+\sin{\alpha}|Co\rangle </math> where α denotes the mixing angle. Partial compositeness is naturally realized in the gauge sector where an analogous phenomenon happens [[quantum chromodynamics]] and is known as [[photon]]–[[rho meson|ρ]] mixing. For fermions it is an assumption that in particular requires the existence of heavy fermions with equal quantum numbers to SM [[quarks]] and [[leptons]]. These interact with the Higgs through the mixing. One schematically finds the formula for the SM fermion masses, :<math>\frac{m_f}v\approx \sin \alpha_L \cdot Y \cdot \sin \alpha_R </math> where L and R refer to the left and right mixings, and Y is a composite sector coupling.
The composite particles are multiplets of the unbroken symmetry H. For phenomenological reasons this should contain the custodial symmetry SU(2)xSU(2) extending the electro-weak symmetry SU(2)xU(1). Composite fermions often belong to [[representation of a Lie group|representations]] larger than the SM particles. For example, a strongly motivated representation for left-handed fermions is the (2,2) that contains particles with exotic electric charge 5/3 or –4/3 with special experimental signatures.
Partial compositeness ameliorates the phenomenology of CHM providing a logic why no deviations from the SM have been measured so far. In the so-called anarchic scenarios the hierarchies of SM fermion masses are generated through the hierarchies of mixings and anarchic composite sector couplings. The light fermions are almost elementary while the third generation is strongly or entirely composite. This leads to a structural suppression of all effects that involve first two generations that are the most precisely measured. In particular flavor transitions and corrections to electro-weak observables are suppressed. Other scenarios are also possible<ref>M. Redi and A. Weiler, ''Flavor and CP Invariant Composite Higgs Models'', JHEP 1111, 108 (2011) https://arxiv.org/pdf/1106.6357.pdf.</ref> with different phenomenology.
== Experiments == The main experimental signatures of CHM are: # New heavy partners of Standard Model particles, with SM quantum numbers and masses around a TeV # Modified SM couplings # New contributions to [[flavor (particle physics)|flavor]] observables
Supersymmetric models also predict that every Standard Model particle will have a heavier partner. However, in supersymmetry the partners have a different [[spin (physics)|spin]]: they are bosons if the SM particle is a fermion, and ''vice versa''. In composite Higgs models the partners have the same spin as the SM particles.
All the deviations from the SM are controlled by the tuning parameter ξ. The mixing of the SM particles determines the coupling with the known particles of the SM. The detailed phenomenology depends strongly on the flavor assumptions and is in general model-dependent. The Higgs and the top quark typically have the largest coupling to the new particles. For this reason third [[generation (particle physics)|generation]] partners are the most easy to produce and top physics has the largest deviations from the SM. Top partners have also special importance given their role in the naturalness of the theory.
After the first run of the LHC direct experimental searches exclude third generation fermionic resonances up to 800 GeV.<ref>ATLAS, https://cds.cern.ch/record/1557777/files/ATLAS-CONF-2013-060.pdf</ref><ref>CMS, https://cds.cern.ch/record/1524087/files/B2G-12-012-pas.pdf</ref> Bounds on gluon resonances are in the multi-TeV range<ref>ATLAS, https://cds.cern.ch/record/1547568/files/ATLAS-CONF-2013-052.pdf</ref><ref>CMS, https://cds.cern.ch/record/1545285/files/B2G-12-005-pas.pdf</ref> and somewhat weaker bounds exist for electro-weak resonances.
Deviations from the SM couplings is proportional to the degree of compositeness of the particles. For this reason the largest departures from the SM predictions are expected for the third generation quarks and Higgs couplings. The first have been measured with per mille precision by the [[LEP]] experiment. After the first run of the LHC the couplings of the Higgs with fermions and gauge bosons agree with the SM with a precision around 20%. These results pose some tension for CHM but are compatible with a compositeness scale f~TeV.
The hypothesis of partial compositeness allows to suppress [[Flavor-changing neutral current|flavor violation]] beyond the SM that is severely constrained experimentally. Nevertheless, within anarchic scenarios sizable deviations from the SM predictions exist in several observables. Particularly constrained is [[CP violation]] in the [[Kaon]] system and lepton flavor violation for example the rare decay μ->eγ. Overall flavor physics suggests the strongest indirect bounds on anarchic scenarios. This tension can be avoided with different flavor assumptions.

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} {{unfocused|date=March 2013}} '''Conflict continuum''' is a model or concept used by various [[Social sciences|social science]] researchers in modelling conflict, usually going from low "irritations" to high "explosiveness" intensity.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://research.uiowa.edu/pimgr/?get=conflict |title=Conflict Management |accessdate=2010-11-30 |date=26 July 2007 |publisher=The University of Iowa |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101002222238/https://research.uiowa.edu/pimgr/?get=conflict |archivedate=2 October 2010 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref> These conceptual models facilitate discussion as in "anywhere on the conflict continuum".<ref>{{cite book | last1 = Ruoti | first1 = Tony | title = C412 INTEROPERABILITY: Operational Art in a New Paradigm | publisher = NAVAL WAR COLLEGE | date = 18 June 1993 | location = Newport, RI. | pages = ii | url = http://handle.dtic.mil/100.2/ADA266739 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book | last1 = Hart | first1 = Louis B. | title = Learning from Conflict: A Handbook for Trainers and Group Leaders | chapter = 4. Getting Started | publisher = Human Resources Development Press | year = 1991 | location = Amherst, MA | url = https://books.google.com/?id=j10Y-Tl1GBgC&lpg=SA4-PA3&dq=The%20Conflict%20Continuum&pg=SA4-PA11#v=onepage&q=The%20Conflict%20Continuum&f=false | accessdate = 2010-12-02| isbn = 9780874251593 }}</ref>
==Various continuum models==
=== Elise Boulding's conflict continuum=== [[Elise M. Boulding]] was a Quaker sociologist influenced by the events of World War II. Examining how war becomes peace, she posited a continuum between Wars of Extermination <ref name="HockerW">{{cite book | author = Hocker, Joyce & William W. Wilmot | title = Interpersonal Conflict, 4th Edition | year = 1995 | publisher = Brown & Benchmark, Madison }}</ref> and Transformation.<ref name="GLorg">{{cite web|url=http://www.global-leader.org/gl_history_gmrs.htm |title=History |year=2001 |publisher=The Institute for Global Leadership |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5uxd3ekHA?url=http://www.global-leader.org/gl_history_gmrs.htm |archivedate=14 December 2010 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref>
This is Boulding’s conflict continuum:<ref name="HockerW" /> War of extermination, Limited war, Threat systems (deterrence), Arbitration, Mediation, Negotiation (exchange), Mutual adaptation, Alliance, Co-operation, Integration,<ref name="HockerW" /> Transformation.<ref name="GLorg" />
===Andra Medea=== {{COI|section|date=March 2013}} {{primary sources|section|date=March 2013}} Theorist [[Andra Medea]] seeks to explain how [[individuals]], small groups, [[organizations]], [[family|families]], [[ethnicities]], and even whole [[nations]] function when disputes arise between them. She posits that there are four types or levels of conflict, each operating under distinct rules: 1) ''Problem Solving''; 2) ''Domination''; 3) ''Blind Behavior''; 4) ''Rogue Messiah''.<ref>Andra Medea interviewed by McDonnell, Jerome. [http://www.wbez.org/episode-segments/may-6-1999 "WorldView"]. WBEZ, Chicago. 16 May 1999.</ref>
Each level moving from first to fourth is characterized by increasing degrees of separation from reality, and decreasing degrees of maturity, in this context, defined as the ability to control anger and settle differences without violence or destruction. Problem-solving behavior is based in reality and maturity, and is therefore more rational and mature than domination. Domination is more rational and mature than blind behavior, which is more rational and mature than the Rogue Messiah.<ref name="AMbookA">Medea, Andra. “The Conflict Continuum.” Chicago, 1996. Page 1.</ref>
However, each level moving from fourth to first is more capable than the one below it at forcing victory in a conflict. The Rogue Messiah overpowers blind behavior, blind behavior thwarts domination, and domination deadlocks Problem-solving.<ref name="AMbookA" />
